abstract.label: Abstract
abstract.value:
The Thomas N. Schroth and Raymond A. Schroth, S.J. 
                <emph render="italic">Brooklyn Eagle</emph> collection contains the records of Thomas N. Schroth, the last managing editor of the 
                <emph render="italic">Brooklyn Eagle</emph> and the son of its last publisher and editor, Frank D. Schroth. While the inclusive dates span from 1841 to 1976, the bulk of Thomas Schroth's records cover the final days of the 
                <emph render="italic">Eagle</emph> (1952-1955), the period leading up to and culminating in a Newspaper Guild strike that led to the closing of the newspaper. The labor struggle is documented through newspaper clippings, internal memos, Newspaper Guild meeting bulletins, and correspondence. A smaller portion of the collection is comprised of the papers of Raymond A. Schroth, S.J., first cousin to Thomas Schroth, and contains the notes for his doctoral dissertation in history at George Washington University on the 
                <emph render="italic">Eagle</emph>, subsequently published as 
                <emph render="italic">The Eagle and Brooklyn</emph> (1974). Raymond Schroth's papers cover his correspondence with publishers, his notes, early drafts of the dissertation, and portions of drafts of the book, as well as reviews and correspondence with responses to an author's query he had published. Finally, the collection also contains approximately 50 photographic prints concerning the history of the 
                <emph render="italic">Eagle</emph> in Brooklyn.

Gift of Thomas N. Schroth, presented by Father Raymond A. Schroth, S.J., 1989.

Raymond A. Schroth, S.J. (b. 1933) was Tom's first cousin and has had an illustrious career as a Jesuit priest, journalist, and teacher. He graduated from Fordham College in 1955 with a major in American Civilization and joined the Society of Jesus in 1957. He later earned his Ph.D. in American Thought and Culture from George Washington University, writing his dissertation on the 
                <emph render="italic">Brooklyn Eagle</emph> and its relationship to the city of Brooklyn. He has published eight books, is the author of over 300 articles published in many major news publications, and has served on the faculty of several American colleges and universities. He is currently an Associate Editor at 
                <emph render="italic">America</emph>, a national Catholic weekly.

The Thomas N. Schroth and Raymond A. Schroth, S.J. 
                <emph render="italic">Brooklyn Eagle</emph> collection contains 5.25 linear feet of material spanning the years 1841 to 1976, though the bulk of the material dates between 1952 and 1955. The collection is housed in two record containers and two oversized boxes, and is arranged into three series:

Series 1: Thomas N. Schroth Brooklyn Eagle records 4.71 linear feet 1841-1971 Scope and Contents

This series is located in Record Cartons 1 and 2, as well as Oversize Boxes 3 and 4, and contains the papers and records of Thomas N. Schroth, the last managing editor of the Brooklyn Eagle. The materials include scrapbooks, bound first and centennial issues, and Eagle publications such as pamphlets and booklets. The bulk of this series is comprised of materials documenting the protracted labor struggle between newspaper management and the Eagle unit of the Newspaper Guild during the years 1952 to 1955, consisting mainly of correspondence, internal memos, clippings, Newspaper Guild publications, Guild meeting bulletins, and union contracts. The condition of the items in this series ranges from very poor (clippings and typescripts on poor quality paper) to good (the more recent materials and all correspondence on onionskin paper). Folders are arranged in alphabetical order by subject.

 Series 2: Raymond A. Schroth, S.J. Eagle and Brooklyn papers 0.54 linear feet 1938-1976 Scope and Contents

This series is located in Record Carton 2 and is largely comprised of manuscript and typescript notes written by Raymond Schroth during the preparation of his Ph.D. dissertation at George Washington University, later edited and made into a book with the title The Eagle and Brooklyn. Other materials in these papers include clippings, correspondence, and some college papers.

 Series 3: Photographs V1989.026 0.08 linear feet circa 1840-1955 Scope and Contents

This series comprises the last folder of Record Carton 2 and three photographs in Oversize Box 4. Record Carton 2 contains approximately 50 photographic prints dating from the 19th and 20th centuries. From the dates provided on the versos of some prints, it is estimated that the majority of the photographs were taken during the time period circa 1840 to 1955. Photographs in Record Carton 2 show members of the Schroth family in their capacities as leaders of Brooklyn Eagle operations; a number of other influential individuals in the Eagle's history, including Eagle founder Henry Cruse Murphy, Colonel William Hester, St. Clair McKelway, Walt Whitman, H.V. Kaltenborn, Cleveland Rodgers, Bob Grannis, I. Kaufman, M. Preston, and Brooklyn Democratic Party Boss Hugh McLaughlin; air and ground methods of Eagle delivery; interiors and exteriors of Eagle office buildings; and images of articles from the Eagle and other ephemera that demonstrate the prominence of the Eagle in the local Brooklyn community. Though these prints were donated by Thomas N. Schroth with all other materials in the collection, the versos of several prints attest that they originate from the Brooklyn Public Library's Brooklyn Picture Collection. The three photographs in Oversize Box 4 consist of a group picture of the Schroth family, a portrait of Frank D. Schroth, and a view of the New York City skyline. The dates for these latter three photographs are unknown.
